text: I'm Asif Kapadia I'm the director of
Center I'm going to talk you through
this sequence so this is Japan 1989 this
is the penultimate race in a
championship and Ayrton Senna has to win
the race in order to be Alain Prost for
the World Championship and the way the
film has been constructed it's made a
hundred percent using the archive
footage of the time so what we've done
is we've looked all over the world in
archives in Japan in San Paulo in Brazil
in France in Italy in Paris and in
London particularly in the formula 1
archives owned by Bernie Ecclestone in
order to get all of this footage to
construct a movie our rain was always
for it to play like an action film to
play like a Drama to play like a classic
three-act structure and this is like a
chase scene this is Senna with the
yellow helmet we're only ever in the car
with him following down Alain Prost who
was considered the best driver at the
time and he has to beat him in this race
to win the championship and it's really
this cat-and-mouse race and we had to
take an hour 40 minutes hour 45 race and
construct it and squeeze it down to two
or three minutes and this is a pivotal
moment in championship Senna tries to
overtake and turns into him and this is
very famous because there were two races
that ended in crashes this rivalry
between the two and became so bitter
that in this case frost it to us turns
into Center the following year nineteen
ninety Center is then ahead in points
and he wrecks his own revenge and what
we've done is we've just found footage
from all over the place so this footage
for example in the car with Senate we
found from a Japanese archive owned by
fuji all of this footage here other
footage we've got we've taken from
England and other footage has come from
Brazil so we have the commentary from
Brazil the idea in a way for when you're
watching the film for us to feel like
we're Brazilian to feel on the side of
Senna most of this material has never
been seen a lot of it was on TV but they
use different camera angles much higher
camera positions and our aim was always
to make it for more dramatic and faster
intense little details at the clock were
constructed by Matt Curtis our graphics
guy so every time you see any logos any
information on the screen all of that
has been created to make it feel like
it's in the moment of the archive
footage I love this sequence just for
the fact we stay in the car for the
whole pit stop you know they have to
change the entire front wing but I do it
so quickly fills that we
stopping for ages but it's only last 17
seconds and here we go there's no speed
limit now you've days you have speed
limits on the pit lane but here he's
going like crazy he's got to overtake
this car in order to win the race just
to stay in the championship we have
other footage that we found of Alain
Prost going rather than going back to
the pits going to talk to the stewards
in order to complain a senha had a push
which is again is another very pivotal
moment in history because Senna thinks
if he wins this race is still in a
championship what he doesn't know is off
the track his great rival is already
talking to the people who run the sport
in order to make sure whatever he does
no matter how much he tries to win he
will be disqualified anyway and all of
this footage was put together in such a
way to make it feel hopefully as
exciting and as thrilling as possible
set of fans who remember this race will
get it but people who've never heard of
Senna people have never seen for one in
their life will also be excited by the
material
